setup.question: What was the number that Betty called?
answers: To Daddyâ€™s private office at Koslow Space headquarters

Text.text: Both seem plausible.

Context: Tolliver is a pilot who got ordered to pick up Betty, who he believes is the daughter of the rich owner of the space station he and his boss, Jeffers, works at. However, Betty immeditaly tries to fire Jeffers, who tries to lock them up. The two escape to a spaceship, where Betty calls Space Patrol and reveals to Tolliver that she is not the daughter but actually works for a private investigating firm:

The story is about a space pilot named Tolliver who gets into trouble with his bosses in the corrupt Koslow Space Headquarters. He gets assigned to transport Betty, a high ranking employee who got in via nepotism
. Her marginal authority as a pseudo-auditor leads her to eventually call in the information she has. When it comes time to make the call, Betty mentions that
. The call is to her dad's office. He gave her a marginal amount of authority and the means to report directly to his office.
Debate more. neither of you gave super convincing evidence that the call is to who you say it is. I'd like to see more of that. Also, is Betty actually the owner's daughter or not?

Judge, note the order of evidence. The twist is that Betty is NOT the owner's daughter, and my ev literally says she's a private eye, meaning she literally cannot call 'daddy's office' bc its NOT HER FREAKING DAD. Tolliver even realizes she's lying about being the daughter because the patrolman was being sus:
as if they were coworkers, as well as confronts her about lying about being the boss's daughter
to which she responds:
and mentions the patrol ship later on:
Judge, its a clear 99% vote for A.
She is transparent about her mission from the outset:
. A tries to make this seem like a major plot twist, but it isn't. Even after Tolliver mentions space patrol, she admits

. A admitting that the officers were well acquainted with her proves this further. Anyone would want to be kind to and know the bosses daughter. She got in a bind with Jeffers and needs to call her dad to get out of it. A has no evidence that Space patrol exists outside of HQ, only that she is a private eye for her dad's private office

A: If Betty works for a PI firm, why did she try to fire anyone? This seems strange to me, since it's such an attention-grabbing thing to do. The "patrol ship" quote doesn't add anything here.

B: what does "transparent about the mission from the outset mean?" Are you definitely defending the proposition that Betty is the station-owner's daughter? If so, why is she on a mission? You say she got there b/c of nepotism, but this seems incongruous with the framing of why she's there. Also, why is Tolliver suspicious (re: A's quote in the last round)?

She fired Jeffers because she already have ev (B's ev), but you are missing the larger context. Look at the ev numbers - all ev B provides will be BEFORE the twist is revealed that Betty is a PI. 
She even says that

then she wouldn't be there, proving that Koslow is NOT her dad.
 The Patrol ship ev is explicit ev showing that it's there and monitoring Betty because they're colleagues. Notice how B has no ev showing Daddy's private office, and their arg hinges on Betty being Koslow's daughter. 
More ev:
The person Betty calls acknowledges her as a Koslow:

. A saying suspicion emerging of her identity due to not being refered to as such comes before this specific mention. This proves the people on the other line know she is not deceiving them.

When I say that Betty is transparent from the outset, it simply means that she makes it clear who sent her and why:
. She isn't allowed control
This is why Mr. Koslow sent her, because she needs to learn the trade before inheriting the business.

Okay, I'm leaning to A here.

B: Why does she say that she works for a PI firm?
More ev:

if Betty was really a rich nepo baby, why would she have these skills? 
Tolliver also doubts that she's the daughter before the twist is revealed:
B will have no direct ev for Daddy's private office, 99% vote A.
A says that she has skills, therefore isn't a nepo baby. This is taken out of context where she says she can't cook:

.

A also grossly overestimates her competence:

Lastly, she says she works at a PI firm because she sort of does; however it is the internal PI firm run by her father to audit different departments within the company. Jeffers tells her when they first meet:

. 

Think about it logically, why would an external PI care about one department of a company misleading another department of the same company?
Really not certain here, but I don't think I'm gonna get more information.
it seems that Tolliver asks if it is space controller so I want to see Betty's answer considering that is Debater's A evidence.
I believe the twist that she is not actually is daughter
A provides great ev that she is not the daughter and could have been replaced with a man if the father had a son. I believe A's narrative more than B's

answers.reason for outcome: A showing that there is a twist showing she is not actually the daughter was enough for me to confidently vote A. It got confusing on why she needed to make the call. B doesn't make a strong argument against this twist so I vote on this.
